as i said , they need to re-aim the industry , yes we know money is good , but you can make more money from new / better stuff no?

item.title: Technology
item.dc:creator: Paddy
item.description:
Agreed Max, its not the hardware thats the problem, its the software. The end user also limmits the advancement. Technology wont push as far if we cant afford it. No company is going to make each component costs thousends and attempt to throw it into the mainstream if we cant have it.

Read full topic

item.title: Technology
item.dc:creator: MaxTheLimit
item.description:
iKy:

to put it short , it’s not too late to reinvent the wheel , to start over differently

GPU capabilities are actually developing rather quickly at the moment.
What is holding many things back is the software side, and consoles holding back major titles that would otherwise push hardware more.
Because cross platform games do better financially, in general, many new games are designed for consoles as well as PCs Because it’s been a while since a next gen console came out games aren’t pushing hardware because you need it to scale to the relatively old hardware currently running consoles.

Read full topic

item.title: Technology
item.dc:creator: iKy
item.description:
MaxTheLimit:

GPUs are already powerful in their own right. You can’t just plunk a Corei7 CPU and make it a reasonable graphics chip. They don’t work that way. Just look at what happens when you CPU is forced to do graphical tasks. It fails miserably.

to put it short , it’s not too late to reinvent the wheel , to start over differently

Read full topic

item.title: Technology
item.dc:creator: sersoft
item.description:
MaxTheLimit:

Intel is working on a core that is both CPU, and GPU but it’s ability to compete with current gen discrete GPUs is going to make it a non factor.

Whatever intel is working on, it’s probably gonna fail in terms of gaming.

Read full topic

item.title: Technology
item.dc:creator: MaxTheLimit
item.description:
GPUs are already powerful in their own right. You can’t just plunk a Corei7 CPU and make it a reasonable graphics chip. They don’t work that way. Just look at what happens when you CPU is forced to do graphical tasks. It fails miserably.
Considering that GDDR5[/SIZE] is already in use on video cards, I don’t think you should get too caught up on that. Memory bandwidth and latency isn’t as much a bottleneck as sheer GPU power.
Intel is working on a core that is both CPU, and GPU but it’s ability to compete with current gen discrete GPUs is going to make it a non factor.

Read full topic

item.title: Technology
item.dc:creator: iKy
item.description:
MaxTheLimit:

transfer rates aren’t the problem.
PCIexpress2.0 only has a tranfer rate of 500MB/s, and we aren’t even close to touching that yet. It’s about GPU power that is the limiting factor.
According to Microsoft reps the Xbox 360 is just over half way through it’s life cycle. It seems doubtfull that they will be releasing any time soon.
Although consoles do continue to sell after they are replaced by new gen, ‘just over half way’ seem like there is a long way to go.

what exactly is keeping them from making video cards with i7 processors and tri-channel 4 gb ddr3’s 2000 hz memories? , i know they will cost as much as a computer , but they will last 20 years as far as performance goes ,

also

[was written before the 1st paragraph ] it seems that the selling of ps2 has accelerated in romania due to price cuts , it seems that my county will always be found to this theory ," wait t’il it gets cheap and not dead" , it’s hard to imagine that any time soon the playstation 2 will die , but the xbox seems to have , did it die or romania just isn’t one of the coutries that it’s publictated ?

Read full topic

item.title: Technology
item.dc:creator: MaxTheLimit
item.description:
There is no such thing as dual SLI’s.
There is only SLi configuration consisting of a certain number of nvidia GPUs.
Dual, tripple, and quad SLi configuration.
/pedant

Read full topic
